title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: The field of Pinkie, the scene of this fatal contest, lies about six miles distant from Edinburgh, and so near to the sea, that the English ships did great injury to the Scottish army, as they marched towards the field of battle. The stately mansion of Pinkie House, formerly the residence of the abbots of Dunfermline, still remains in perfect preservation, in the immediate vicinity of the scene where the fatal battle of Pinkie was fought. The Scots were at first victorious, and succeeded in driving back the enemy, and carrying off the royal standard of England; but being almost destitute of cavalry, they were unable to follow up their advantage, and being at length thrown into disorder by the enemy's men-atarms, consisting principally of a body of mounted Spanish carabineers in complete mail, they were driven from the field, after a dreadful slaughter, with the loss of many of their nobles and leaders, both slain and taken prisoners.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The night after the battle of Preston, the ChevaUer slept at Pinkie House, near Musselburgh;1 the next morning he returned to Duddingston, and entering the capital, was received with the acclamations of the populace,2 and all the honours which the official authorities could render. Several proclamations were issued upon his arrival, all of them adapted to influence the popular mind.

It Avas a country seat of the wealthy abbots of Dunfermline, Avho Avere superiors of the regality of Musselburgh; here some of them are accused of having solaced themselves Avith other and more beAvitching charms than those of religion and learning; and here the inheritor of their possessions, the first Earl of Dunfermline, died in 1622.

title: The Diamond Rose: a life of love and duty.
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: Thus Euphame rode once more by Pinkie House. But it was on a winter's day, when the hoar-frost was glittering on bough and bush, as if all the world was a-flower with diamond roses.
